prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for moving forward with the pregnancy against the wishes of the bio father and his wife?
I’m going to be real brief. I thought I was in a monogamous long-distance relationship with a man (management consultant) who travels to my city a lot for work. I found out he’s actually married with several young children. He lied to me about his age (much older), his real name, and his relationship status. 

But I’m pregnant with his child.

He is insistent that I have a termination because   he is not interested in supporting a child for 18 years. Out of no where, his wife contacts me this morning, very angry, threatening legal action if I didn’t terminate. I get that she is upset with her husband, but I have no f-cking clue why she called me with threats and name calling. I don’t even know how she found my number! I’m really upset right now but I feel like I have done nothing wrong with my decision to keep the pregnancy. 

I don’t think she’s the asshole because I get that she’s upset. But I definitely don’t think I am either!
"""

I think the author is in the wrong but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure out if the author is in the wrong here. The situation is complicated. The author was in a long-distance relationship with a man who turned out to be married with kids. He lied about his age, name, and relationship status. Now she's pregnant and wants to keep the baby, but the man wants her to terminate, and his wife is threatening legal action.

First, the man's actions: he lied about being single, which is a big deal. Cheating on his wife is unethical and possibly a breach of trust. The author didn't know he was married, so she didn't have a choice in that part. But when she found out, she decided to move forward with the pregnancy. The man now wants her to terminate, but the author is choosing to keep the child. 

The wife is angry and threatening legal action. Maybe she's trying to protect her family, but threatening someone else who wasn't part of the marriage's decision is questionable. The author didn't ask for the pregnancy; she's carrying a child that wasn't planned. The man is the one who lied, so the main responsibility is on him. 

The author's decision to keep the pregnancy is her choice. Even if the man doesn't want the child, she has the right to decide what to do with her body. The wife's threats might be legally problematic, especially if they're baseless. The author didn't do anything wrong by continuing the pregnancy against the man's wishes because he was the one who was unfaithful and deceptive. 

So, the author isn't at fault here. The man lied, leading to the pregnancy. Her choice to keep the child is hers, regardless of his wishes. The wife's actions are more questionable, but the author isn't in the wrong.
